repnme.cdata!:
Azerbaijan - Rehabilitation and Completion
            of Irrigation and Drainage Infrastructure Project

abstracts.cdata!:
Ratings for the Rehabilitation and
            Completion of Irrigation and Drainage Infrastructure Project
            for Azerbaijan were as follows: outcomes were satisfactory,
            the risk to development outcome was moderate, the Bank
            performance was satisfactory, and the Borrower performance
            was satisfactory. Some lessons learned included:
            agricultural development plays a pivotal role in poverty
            reduction in Azerbaijan. Properly operating Irrigation and
            Drainage (I&D) infrastructure is essential for good
            agricultural production in the country. Adequate public
            investments for rehabilitation and modernization of I&D
            systems are needed to reverse the ongoing deterioration of
            systems and make them more efficient. Azerbaijan has limited
            water resources and competing demands for water resources
            are increasing. Future I&D investments also have to
            address as one of its main objectives the improvement and
            sustainable use of water through integrated water resources
            management from the river basin perspective. Considering the
            current state of much of the I&D infrastructure in the
            country, for rehabilitation purposes a system approach has
            to be adopted, allowing an in-depth analysis of major
            shortcomings of an entire irrigation or drainage system in
            order to propose the necessary improvements in light of an
            overall objective of restoring capacity, increasing
            efficiency, and improving Operation and Maintenance
            (O&M). The rehabilitation of I&D infrastructure,
            institutional reforms in water management, the development
            of Water Users Associations (WUAs) for ensuring their
            professional and financial independence, and the transfer to
            WUAs of the public I&D infrastructure are all necessary
            instruments for improving in a holistic manner the
            efficiency and sustainability of irrigated agriculture in Azerbaijan.

repnme.cdata!:
Azerbaijan - Rehabilitation and Completion
            of Irrigation and Drainage Infrastructure Project -
            additional financing

abstracts.cdata!:
The additional credit for the Azerbaijan
            Rehabilitation and Completion of Irrigation and Drainage
            Infrastructure Project will help finance a cost overrun to
            complete irrigation and drainage infrastructure works under
            the original project. The cost overrun mainly occurred due
            to: (1) an increase during the last few years in the price
            of construction materials, in particular steel and cement,
            and fuel; and (2) a greater than anticipated volume of
            rehabilitation work for one component of the project. The
            additional financing will be required to fund all the
            originally planned activities in full, specifically the
            rehabilitation and enlargement of the Samur-Apsheron Canal
            (SAC) main supply system from km 27 to 50. It will thus
            mainly be used to carry out the last civil works contract,
            but there will also be small allocations to finance
            consultants. The original project development objectives and
            expected outcomes will remain unchanged.

repnme.cdata!:
Azerbaijan - Rehabilitation and Completion
            of Irrigation and Drainage Infrastructure Project

abstracts.cdata!:
The Rehabilitation and Completion of
            Irrigation and Drainage Infrastructure Project aims to
            prevent the decline in supplying water to Baku City,
            eliminate further deterioration of the supply of irrigation
            water to approximately 86,000 hectares (ha) along the
            Sumur-Apsheron Canal; and improve drainage and reduce water
            logging and salinity on approximately 36,500 ha along
            Main-Mugan Collector. The project constitutes three
            components: 1) Rehabilitation and completion of irrigation
            and drainage infrastructure will support rehabilitation of
            critical main infrastructure of the Samur-Apsheron Canal
            (SAC) System, which comprises a headworks across the Samur
            river, a main supply canal, a reservoir near Baku City,
            pumping stations, three sediment basins, and a number of
            secondary canals that supply water to the irrigation areas.
            2) Institutional strengthening will support institutional
            development to make a start with the improvement of the
            quality and sustainability of irrigation management by
            supporting technical assistance to review the work practice
            of SAC and training. 3) Project implementation support will
            cover part of the incremental staff salaries and operational
            expenses of the Project Implementation Unit, and the annual
            monitoring and evaluation.

repnme.cdata!:
Azerbaijan - Rehabilitation of Irrigation
            and Drainage Infrastructure Project : environmental assessment

abstracts.cdata!:
The Rehabilitation of Irrigation and
            Drainage Infrastructure Project, will adversely affect
            sensitive and protected areas, around the Ag-Gol, and Sarisu
            Lakes, as well as at the Samur Aspheron Canal, and the Main
            Mill Mugan collector, endangering flora, and fauna. However,
            it is anticipated that construction impacts will be minimal,
            and preventive measures would include environmental
            precautionary clauses in the bidding documents. Likewise,
            the reduction of drainage discharges, and seasonal drainage
            congestion will be relieved, consequently water logging, and
            salinity will correspondingly decrease, allowing positive
            impacts on the area's ecology. Nonetheless mitigating
            measures call for a monitoring program, to assess natural
            parks, and bio-diversity; hydrological, and hydro-geological
            flow regimes; soil degradation, and land use; water quality;
            health surveillance; and socioeconomic aspects, to comply
            with appropriate environmental guidelines.
